Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Phylogenetics and Floral Symmetry Development of the Core Goodeniaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The seemingly endless diversity of flower shapes and colors captivates humans but evolved to entice pollinators in one of the most intricate and crucial biological interactions. This project tests the impact of floral diversity on speciation in the plant family Goodeniaceae, which is closely related to the large sunflower family. Goodeniaceae (400+ species) is one of the most species-rich and beautiful plant families in Australia and the Pacific Islands, and is particularly important to the Southwestern Australian Floristic Province, a threatened global biodiversity hotspot. The current taxonomic classification of these plants does not accurately reflect their evolutionary history, so a comprehensive revision of the group will be made using DNA sequences. Digital image analysis, floral symmetry gene expression, and the patterns of symmetry throughout development will be examined to quantify the species' floral shape. Hypotheses of the impact of these shapes on rates of diversification will be assessed using this new information.

Undergraduate researchers will help study the interaction of insect pollinators with a subset of species in Western Australia. Students from the diverse communities of Memphis, Tennessee and Queens, New York will be an integral part of the project and will gain expertise in many aspects of molecular and evolutionary biology. This project will also help establish the conservation status of new and potentially rare species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the evolutionary history and floral shape changes in the plant family Goodeniaceae. This family is the most diverse in Australia and on Pacific Islands. It is well known for having interesting flower morphology, with extreme cases of flowers in which all of the petals are on the lower half of the flower. This gives the flowers an appearance of being cut in half, which has resulted in myths and legends about this group, especially in Pacific Islands. Our collaborators on this grant, PI Dr. Rachel Jabaily, at Rhodes College, and Dr. Kelly Shepherd, at the Western Australian Herbarium determined the evolutionary relationships of the groups in Australia, which has informed the taxonomy and conservation of the family. We also aided our collaborators in statistically analyzing the changes in shape of the flowers across species, pinpointing the major types of shape. In order to collect plant samples, myself, two undergraduates from St. John's University, and three undergraduates and a postdoc from Rhodes College traveled to Perth, Australia. We traveled throughout western Australia, with the help of Dr. Kelly Shepherd, at the Western Australian Herbarium. These students learned how to collect plants, how to properly make herbarium specimens, and the laws around collecting and conservation in Australia. When the two St. John's University undergraduates arrived back in NY, they oversaw a project extracting RNA from the plants that they had collected.

            Our portion of this collaborative project focused on examining the genes that control the shape of the flowers in Goodeniaceae. We sequenced portions of CYCLOIDEA (CYC)-like genes, which regulate flower symmetry.  We sequenced CYC-like genes from across 60 species of Goodeniaceae and determined that there is a single copy of each of CYC1 and CYC2, and a broad duplication in CYC3. We further dissected floral buds, separating the petals to examine expression of these genes and how it changes from the upper to lower petals. We found that CYC2 genes had a similar upper petal expression to what has been characterized in other flowering plants. CYC3, on the other hand, had higher expression in the lower petal, the opposite pattern. However, this pattern of higher expression was only seen in the flowers that appeared as "half," which had all of their petals on the lower side, suggesting that their differential expression plays a role in this morphology.

            We additionally used genomic data from our collaborators to further examine CYC and test the utility of shallow genome sequencing, a quick way to get small fragments of the genome. We tested different ways to assemble the genomic data in order to be able to uncover the most nuclear gene data, and successfully found fragments of CYC like gene copies from nearly all the species sampled.

Through the course of this funded grant we have published 2 papers, have one manuscript under revision, and two in preparation. PI Howarth also was part of 3 additional publications with the collaborative team. We presented three talks at a symposium on Goodeniaceae, and posters at the Botany Meetings in Edmonton, CANADA (2015), Savannah, GA (2016), and Forth Worth, TX (2017). Two undergraduate students traveled to Australia for two weeks and worked extensively in the lab or 2 years. One of these students has now started a PhD in Plant Biology. These students also created a teaching module that they presented to Girl Scout troops in the area, about flower form and how to extract DNA.
